Solving a system of two equations using the inverse matrix

If we have one linear equation \( ax=b\) in which the unknown is \(x\) and \(a\) and \(b\) are constants and \(a\neq 0\) then \(x=\dfrac{b}{a}= a^{-1}b\).

What happens if we have more than one equation and more than one unknown? In this worksheet we copy the algebraic solution \(x=a^{-1}b\) used for a single equation to solve a system of linear equations. As we shall see, this will be a very natural way of solving the system if it is first written in matrix form.

Consider the system \[\begin{matrix} 2x_1 & + & 3x_2&= & 5 \\ x_1 & - & 2x_2&= & -1. \end{matrix} \] In matrix form this becomes \[\qquad \left[\begin{array}{rr} 2&3\\ 1&-2\end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c}x_1\\ x_2\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}5\\ -1\end{array}\right]\ \ \quad\text{which is of the form}\ \quad AX=B.\]

If \(A^{-1}\) exists then the solution is \[\qquad X=A^{-1}B.\qquad\text{(compare the solution} \ x=a^{-1}b \ \text{above)}\]
